systems.sysdata package¶

Submodules¶

systems.sysdata.configdata module¶

systems.sysdata.data module¶

Core data object - Base class

Data objects are used to get data from a particular source, and give certain information about it

This bare Data class isn’t much good and holds only price data

Normally we’d extend this for specific asset classes (eg carry data for futures), and then for a
specific source of data (eg csv files, databases, ...)

The inheritance is:

Base generic class: Data -> asset class specific eg futuresdata.FuturesData -> source specific eg legacy.csvFuturesData

class systems.sysdata.data.Data(pricedict={})¶

Bases: object

data=Data(dict(a=pd.DataFrame(...), b=pd.DataFrame(...)) print(data.get_instrument_list()) print(data.

list of instruments in this data set

systems.sysdata.futuresdata module¶

class systems.sysdata.futuresdata.FuturesData(pricedict={}, carrydatadict={})¶

Bases: sysdata.data.Data

Get futures specific data

Will normally be overriden by a method for a specific data source See legacy.py

get_instrument_rawcarrydata(instrument_code)¶

Returns a pd. dataframe with the 4 columns PRICE, CARRY, PRICE_CONTRACT, CARRY_CONTRACT

These are specifically needed for futures trading

For other asset classes we’d probably pop in eg equities fundamental data, FX interest rates...

Normally we’d inherit from this method for a specific data source

systems.sysdata.legacy module¶

Get legacy data from .csv files

Used for quick examples / ‘scaffolding’
